<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_maximize_write_buffer:
```c
static size_t
connection_maximize_write_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MemoryPool *const pool = connection->pool;
  void *new_buf;
  size_t new_size;
  size_t free_size;

  mhd_assert ((NULL != c->write_buffer) || (0 == c->write_buffer_size));
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset >= c->write_buffer_send_offset);
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_size >= c->write_buffer_append_offset);

  free_size = MHD_pool_get_free (pool);
  if (0 != free_size)
  {
    new_size = c->write_buffer_size + free_size;
    /* This function must not move the buffer position.
     * MHD_pool_reallocate () may return the new position only if buffer was
     * allocated 'from_end' or is not the last allocation,
     * which should not happen. */
    mhd_assert ((NULL == c->write_buffer) || \
                MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool, c->write_buffer, \
                                               c->write_buffer_size));
    new_buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                   c->write_buffer,
                                   c->write_buffer_size,
                                   new_size);
    mhd_assert ((c->write_buffer == new_buf) || (NULL == c->write_buffer));
    c->write_buffer = new_buf;
    c->write_buffer_size = new_size;
    if (c->write_buffer_send_offset == c->write_buffer_append_offset)
    {
      /* All data have been sent, reset offsets to zero. */
      c->write_buffer_send_offset = 0;
      c->write_buffer_append_offset = 0;
    }
  }

  return c->write_buffer_size - c->write_buffer_append_offset;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation:
I inspected all controlling expressions in the function. The following are the only controlling expressions present: the three mhd_assert(...) usages, the if (0 != free_size) { ... } branch, and the nested if (c->write_buffer_send_offset == c->write_buffer_append_offset) { ... } branch. None of these are compile-time/invariant controlling expressions:

- mhd_assert(...) invocations use runtime fields (c->write_buffer, c->write_buffer_size, offsets). Even if mhd_assert is implemented with a do { ... } while(0) macro, that do-while uses the constant 0 intentionally as a macro wrapper; MISRA explicitly permits a do-while with a controlling expression that is an integer constant expression evaluating to false (exception 2), and also the do{...}while(0) idiom does not create an invariant controlling expression in the user code logic.

- if (0 != free_size) depends on free_size returned by MHD_pool_get_free(pool) (a runtime value), so it is not invariant.

- if (c->write_buffer_send_offset == c->write_buffer_append_offset) depends on runtime-modifiable structure members and thus is not invariant.

There are no loops with invariant conditions (no while/for/do-while that create infinite loops except possible macro wrapping explained above), and no controlling expression is a compile-time constant used as part of program control flow. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
